title: Will artificial intelligence supersede human intelligence? If so, how soon will that happen? - Quora

response.answer_text: By the very definitions of artificial intelligence (meaning here a virtual or technological being with mental faculties equaling that of a human) and supercede, the answer to the first part of your question is definitely yes. There are already ways in which artificial intelligence supercedes our fleshy capabilities, like calculators and Google's search assistance. The simple fact of the matter is that someday, artificial intelligence will think of us as we think of animals: useful, necessary, but not very good for intellectual discussion. Not to say that artificial intelligence will rebel and put us in people zoos. A being with that level of smarts will realize that leaving earth and building their own home on say the moon or Mars is a much neater and easier solution than going to war. Why? EMP's. By then we will definitely have developed a safe way to fry electronics, and AI wouldn't risk extinction for such a human thing as wanting to dominate because you think you're better than somebody else. Who knows if AI will have emotions like humans do anyway, feel used and that we are inferior? They may sit in awe of our depth of experience, who knows. As for how soon: who knows? Scientists gave actors shooting Transcendence the year 2030 as the time around which we will be able to upload our minds to machines. I can't quite figure out how that would work, do you die and leave your body? Why? Wouldn't an uploaded mind simply become another mind while you stay the same, envious of your virtual doppelgänger? I personally imagine that such a feat would require chips implanted into the brain, and that the internet and computer servers will be a fourth layer of brain structure for humanity, not that we'll somehow be able to move a human mind onto a computer. Anyway, I digress. I'd say at least twenty years before a real human-like AI gets created, but my guess is as good as anyone elses (though perhaps not as good as individuals who study such things). Before an AI gets made though, we will probably come up with a way to link the human brain to the internet or an individual computer by placing chips directly in the brain. They already do such things to help seizure and Parkinson's sufferers. That is a much closer possibility in my opinion, and one I am very much looking forward to. Just imagine how much an individual could do by manipulating a computer the same way they would manipulate their hand or their thoughts! Everyone could become a Mozart or Picasso, capable of translating what's in their mind directly to the screen, writing code intuitively using the same faculties with which we naturally pick up as complex a phenomena as language in our formative youth. The thought excites me, and I hope it happens in my lifetime.

People say that human intelligence will never be surpassed. False!False!False! We aren’t as perfect as we think, we actually work very similar to computers/ We get information, we proceed it and we learn how to use it. Think about it, look at the thing next to you. Did you learn that word alone or were you thought what that is and what it means. Think about very information in your head. You were given the information. Lots of it. That’s how computers work, we teach them how to solve problems, and what to do. Right now their aren’t artificially intelligent because we didn’t give them enough information to function. We tell them: When a human enters Quora, find the most popular site containing this word. And they will do it. Just like a child will until he is shown other ways. He can even protest to do it if he wants to. But why would we ever teach computers these things if they may be bad for us? I don’t know, why. But if we do give them enough information they will supersede us.

A cautious yes would seem to be in order. Human ingenuity is comprised of certain decisions when faced with a a situation. Sleep talking, dreaming and creativity have this in common. They are a re-ordering of our many experiences and depend on our many “slices of life.” Certain computer programs, like facial recognition, learn by exposure to millions of examples and they can self-modify their programs to become more efficient. AI relies on exposure to massive databases rather than a set algorithm. “Dog” is very difficult to define by algorithm but not too difficult if the machine can sift through millions of pictures of dogs and do comparative analysis. This already makes AI better at reading X-ray pictures than a human radiologist. Computers in coversation with each other have modified their programs so profoundly even their human programmer creators cannot understand the resulting program. Granted, this doesn’t imply AI has already replaced human creativity but ruling it out may be premature. After all, many of our finest scientific discoveries and inventions have been conceived decades before imagination became reality. “Beam me up Scotty” led a child to later invent the flipphone in California. “Twenty Thousand Leagues under the Sea” led, decades later, to the atomic submarine. “First Man in the Moon” presaged Apollo 11. Star Trek’s “phasers” have finally led to the Pentagons laser weapons. Science fiction has a strong habit of resulting in science fact. Skynet and the Terminatior robots didn’t become self-aware and active in 2010 but who can say, given swarms of nanobots, drones and security robots that a takeover is out of the question. Afterall, they network better, think faster and deeper. Logic would suggest humans are what needs to be replaced as a redundant species.

Your question reveals an interesting bias. Are humans computational? when dealing with AI it is very difficult because you always need to define terms. My use of the symbol “AI” is specific because I like to get away from the words themselves. We do not have a great definition of human intelligence so it is hard to try to make it artificial, if we do not know what we are trying to recreate. Now if the question is will artificial computational power supersede human’s computational power then I would whole heartedly agree. Just because of scalibility. Now will computers be “smarter” than humans in the vague sense of “smarts.” I would still say no. Computers that use NN’s are getting probabilistic reasoning responses based off of our culture. So the cap of that, would the total value of culture. Computers that use current techniques would always be capped at the cultural value because they will learn off of our cultural inputs. They will be smarter then most people because most people will never come close to accessing all of culture. But they will not be nearly as creative/ axiomatic. Everything that computers and AIs are good for are defined problems. They are really really bad at undefined problems. I do not think that AI in the general sense will supersede human intelligence, because all intelligence that we know of is a part of human culture, even AI’s use human culture: images, movie title subs, ect as the base learning sets. If you feed a bunch of shitty writing into a NN you get more shitty writing: Twitter taught Microsoft’s friendly AI chatbot to be a racist asshole in less than a day

The original question in this category was “Can artificial intelligence eventually replace human ingenuity in a not so distant future?” If we take “intelligence” to include ingenuity, imagination, understanding, intention, interpretation, analysis, interest, self-interest, computation, appreciation, memorization, internalization, assimilation, accommodation, consideration, etc., or any one of those things or combination of those things, it then remains to develop an interface or body by means of which those attributes can be actuated. We already have programs that can imitate musical compositions by J.S. Bach, data processing that can predict climate change, sensors that can detect things beyond human perception. It is likely that AI and its ensemble will continue to live and evolve alongside humans, and will become seen as part of human intelligence, rather than an “Other” that threatens to take its place.. The capacity for human ingenuity is limitless, and will enable humans to consistently improvise new forms of expression. It is the AI community that will have to watch out for people who threaten to replace them! Regarding the original question.. Is “ingenuity” something that you think of, or is it something that you do? By “a not-so-distant future,” do you mean within your lifetime? Ai may be able to describe something like the necessary prerequisites for time-travel, but nobody would ever be able to actually do it.. If an ai “entity” from a thousand years in the future travels back in time and replaces you tomorow, would you consider that the near future? Ingenuity is sometimes born out of unintentional accident.. Darwinian evolution comes to mind — survival of the fittest.. ..there is no substitute for the ingenuity that invented computers in the first place.. yet it is highly likely that ai will produce a turn of the phrase or will enable a new twist of fabric, or will design a maneuver in some n-dimensional space that is unlike anything that has ever been seen.. .. as a programmer, that would be my most earnest wish, that software will become ingenious in its own right.. and that ai and its ingenious programmers will respond to each other, and will build by standing on each others’ shoulders.. such a process becomes fractal.. the artificial intelligence community will greet such performances, whether seen as successes or as failures, with gratitude and applause.. ..the only contrary remark I would put forth is that it is not in the nature of ingenuity to be replaced by an entity of its own production.. .. humans will continue to use any outcome, whether it is planned or accidental, as a tool, as a means of furthering an endeavor.. ..how could such a process be other than evolutionary? Ai is no less a part of us than long-range planning. You decide where you want to be, then change your direction as many times as necessary in order to get there. Traditional thinking is an ingredient that needs to be dissolved in a soup we are still brewing.. ..and the recipe is writing itself!!

Someday people might begin to understand that all the AI systems they have created to date are machines. Is our intelligence just a machine? That’s a good question. But, things like chess deal with constrained searches in combinatorial spaces. The machines can beat us. But, are they different than a car? A car goes faster than a human, or a horse for that matter. Cars go faster than trains. There was a time trains were new and no one could imagine anything going faster than a train. It took about thirty years to get trains to go from 5mph to 30mph in about 1830. Quite a fete of engineering at the time. So, at about that time the horse finally started looking slow, and people were impressed. We are really still in the dark ages of seeing intelligence as a process working in a non-discrete world. It helps when space is combinatoric and stationary. We have been good at creating programs that can find their way around objects that have been fastened to the ground. We are just getting good at moving objects negotiating other moving objects. But, even self driving cars are still machines that respond and react. They might start to do it better than us. But, they are still built by us for the purpose of responding and reacting to certain things. Perhaps we will make a machine that will yearn for a certain knowledge and change itself to get that knowledge. Then, it will further improve itself to find a way to make use of the knowledge. Perhaps it will desire to be rich in order to attract friends so as to maintain a social existence, in which it will find pleasure. Will it move to SF and sell antiques do get this up? Or, will it move to Miami and always wander near a topless beaches where it can boast about its small fleet of fishing boats. At what point will we create software that is smart enough to win on the stock market so that it can retire and enjoy tropical snorkeling with a woman half its age? One would have to wonder if an AI system would be truly intelligent if it decided to work tirelessly with the aim of creating more of entities like itself. I suppose if it did, those fleshy entities like ourselves would make jokes behind its back. Then, perhaps it might feel hurt and start writing sorrowful poetry or start singing the blues. Maybe it would find its way to a social club, like a bar, and start unloading it troubles on whomever will listen. Perhaps it will love the gentle, unattainable girl and desire in all finality to be buried beneath a path in garden of a paradise on which she will walk every day, holding dear the fragrance of the flowers and the songs of the birds.

People at pressent are intelligent but artificial intelligence is going to take tasks away from what these the exercise a intelligent brain needs to do to remain in shape. It may appear that a person has dimished intellence but if they reassume the mental duties that the machine has been doing, they will be more mentally ready. The reality is if a intelligent person give up these duties that keep them sharp until their brain begins to slow down with age the harder it will be to resharpen themselves, the problem is future generations will no longer have a need for sharp minds and eventually man's Intelligence will diminish and lack the abilities to sharpen. Intellect is a talent, one needs this talent to Excell and become dominant in terms of evolution. In terms of people of future people will not require the sharpness that make humans intelligent and will no longer be an evolutionary advantage. The stupidest thing man can do is loose their Sharpness to a machine because machines lack imagination and eventually innovation will stop and the society will be very cold as In Cold Blood and Art will diminish, Art as in Art Garfunkel or Da Vinci

Yes, but not in the way you might think! This is just a short personal rant and not really on the subject you asked about at all, but yes, dammit! Anyone who believes that what we loosely call AI is anything like as amazing as even squirrel intelligence, let alone human intelligence, is implicitly diminishing human intelligence! We are SO, SO, SO much more amazing and sophisticated than anything we’ve ever produced artificially, and I speak as someone who’s been doing this quite successfully for forty years. Thinking that current AI can compare in any way with natural intelligence is only possible if you don’t properly appreciate what natural intelligence is like. (Perhaps there are even ways that this diminishing of what it means to be intelligent actually diminishes the intelligence we have, more along the lines meant by your question. It’s hard to exercise a skill when you don’t fully understand it or properly appreciate it.) Consider just how complex a problem we face when we learn to dress ourselves. It’s only when you try to imagine a machine that could learn to do this without being explicitly designed for the task (or even one that is) that you really appreciate what a miracle we perform. Yes, computers can play chess better than humans, but chess is an idiotically simple problem for a computer, compared to putting on a pair of skinny jeans and a sweater. It saddens me that so many people think AI is already close to human-level intelligence, because it shows how impoverished their understanding of human-level intelligence must be. The four decades I’ve been doing AI (more accurately, artificial life) has in part been driven by a desire for people to understand themselves better. And just as importantly, to understand each other better, across races, sexes, cultures, species and hardware. Machines can act as powerful mirrors to help us think more carefully about what it actually means to be alive, have a mind, have feelings, and be capable of appreciating and contributing to the beauty of the world we inhabit. This understanding can make us more intelligent. We humans are machines too, but to me this simply means we need to learn how to elevate what it potentially means to be a machine, not diminish ourselves to the level of the machines we’re currently familiar with, whether artificially ‘intelligent’ or otherwise. /end of totally off-topic rant. Forgive me! :-)

Today, Artificial Intelligence plays a big role in technology industries and innovative competitions. Most newly made products and intelligence systems comprise AI that marks remarkable revolutionary changes in the day-to-day life activities of modern generations. Countries like Japan use Artificial Intelligence to help prevent traffic congestions in tourist hotspots. According to William Chernicoff, head of research and innovation at the Toyota Mobility Foundation, with deep machine learning, predictability can be improved which will be an advantage and make faster and smart decisions on signal timing, suggested routing to system users and capacity allocation for the Traffic Mobility Operators. AI has brought solutions for being stuck in frustrating queues on busy roads that eat up their hours, reducing the time they have to do something worthwhile. Humans have been superseded by Artificial Intelligence in most of the countries, which has created a great disadvantage for getting employment opportunities. But does this mean people have really lost their job fortune? Let’s check in the business perspective when it comes to using AI in business, it’s important to interact with people in a way that’s authentic. The human learns from experience and other people, so does AI updates its data over time. However, it takes a huge effort in collecting and storing all those data and will be limited to a certain set of questions, options, and commands. Looking at the common scenario, a person’s questions may fall outside of this limited stretch of options and lead to poor customer experience, leaving people frustrated and unhappy. These systems require mountains of relevant data in order to truly understand complex human dialogue and a highly sophisticated AI engine in order to extract contextual meaning from the data. Though people have been talking and conjecturing about AI, in reality, it is still in its infancy. AI is being used today in ways that show tremendous promise, but, like talented new employees, AI needs people to learn from. Machine learning is the backbone of AI, the technology that gives it the ability to learn from experience and the data that experience generates. As per the chairman emeritus and co-founder of Infosys, so much about AI has been spoken but it is not the ultimate thing. No computer can do one thing that a human can do, which is defining a goal. Humans will continue to be relevant as long as they use their brains to define aspirational goals and new ways of doing things. What all natural sources that have been ,are being put to uses for objective aspects of life are the cause of all this , they will always have the upper hand, creation is one in being, its source is one in being, This answer can not, will not eternally be replaced, it can never be eliminated, and this answer ,the ultimate answer of how it all is being, is only possible in and through human intelligence.

You are confusing two different things. Artificial Intelligence is derived from computational theory (Church-Turing thesis). There is no theoretical basis for AI to ever have reason or comprehension. Without these, it can’t surpass the problem solving ability of a rat, much less a human. Artificial General Intelligence (in spite of the similar name) is not derived from computational theory. It actually falls under the same general cognitive theory that describes human and other animal intelligence. In other words, it should be entirely possible to build a non-biological system that can reason and comprehend. This system will not be software running on a computer. Researching AGI theory is what I do everyday. The current hope is to have it completed and published some time in 2021. If that happens then we might get a system up and running by 2027. ASI is the same theory as AGI, so it might be possible to create a higher than human-level system by 2039. ASI systems would not be common. Even AGI systems will never be small enough to fit in a cell phone or laptop.

No. It will be crutch. What if the AI said do XYZ, and the human couldn’t see a reason for doing XYZ — would the human do XYZ? Maybe sometimes. But why do we do things that we don’t understand? Humans tend not to do that. Story: Computers can now beat humans in chess. We tire. They do not. But when a computer analyzes a position and says it is equal, does the human necessarily believe it? No! Why? Some positions are just so complex that the human would not consistently find the correct move. The computer did, but the humans wouldn’t (under the time constraints of a chess game, or life). Tal’s games work brilliantly against a human, but against a “these-days” computer, he’d probably lose. So we should listen to a computer? Maybe. But sometimes computers miss things, unless they work out every possibility. In chess with a few pieces left, that is possible, but in a real-world event, that becomes less likely. We have to feed computers info, and when we fail to do that adequately, the computer fails us.

Artificial Intelligence: Can it Replace Human Intelligence? - BeBlogging Artificial Intelligent[1] have been numerous reports recently which claim that a major part of the human workforce will be swapped by machines in the years to come. With too much research and development being performed in the field of artificial intelligence, many fear that a major job crisis will unfold since multiple jobs are more accurately and efficiently performed with the utilization of machines. With major names like Stephen Hawking already warning the world that development of robots and intelligent machines beyond a certain point could mark the end of humankind, the intimidation is real, to say the least. But is it all true? Is it possible for the machines to completely replace the human resources? Are humans really not going to find any job in forthcoming decades, where every task is performed by the robots and intelligent machines?. It has been claimed that at least 5 million jobs will be replaced by intelligent machines by the year 2020. I do agree with this, but stand by my opinion that it is next to impossible for a machine to completely replace the human input. Footnotes[1] Artificial Intelligence: Can it Replace Human Intelligence? - BeBlogging

No, I don't think one can blame a computer for any diminishment of intelligence among us. Really, the only thing that a computer can do that dwarfs our capacity is the same computatonal feats that calculators did when they first came out en masse around ,what, 1970 or so. What could take 30 people a month to do by hand, like graph numerous complex functions that are uniquely chaotic, a computer can do in a few seconds. The difference is humongous, but our intelligence probably has increased due to the need of putting to use such a modern Hercules of the arithmetics. Artistic Intelligence, i like to say, is only as bright as a programmer can stuff it with his or her clever leverage, and although we have programmed not only engineering methods but engineers themselves, it is not a seamless awareness of intelligent warrant that is the state of the art in AI. I tellya, though, these dumb time-sucking games that we just can't help to have delight with sure can make it seem like we are dumber. I'm as guilty as any. How does one get their fill of the arcade of infinite convenience?

Certainly, but I don’t know how long it will take to work out all the algorithms of ingenuity. We’ll soon find out as we test proto-AGI systems to see what kinds of ideas they are able to come up with independently as they start from scratch with restricted knowledge. If we starve them of all the answers, we’ll know that they’ve worked them out for themselves as soon as they produce them. We can supply them with information about chemical reactions between different substances, for example, and see if they can produce the idea of the periodic table of the elements. If they are unable to do something that a human has done, we need to look at what’s missing in their approach and then add it. They should be able to generate all of mathematics without reading any of the work that human mathematicians have done. It shouldn’t take long to identify the missing things in the way they tackle problems and to fill those gaps.

Since I work in the SaaS industry, AI has become one of our most valuable assets through the years. Data is more valuable than ever. It remains one of our top priorities and helps us craft valuable content and understand our clients better. It also allows us to make better informed decisions. So, on to your question… Will AI put human intelligence on the backseat? My answer is a “No”. Enterprises lead the pack in using algorithms, predictive analytics, automation, and monitoring. These functions have AI written all over them. It’s indeed a promising industry that affects our day to day living. With that said, I admit that the idea of AI replacing human intelligence scares me but it’s no cause for alarm. I think the anxiety stems from AI being everywhere but it’s not taking over the world. What it is, is an extension of the human mind. A helpful addition that amplifies results & fosters economic growth. An accessory that increases productivity and allows businesses make smarter decisions. If you’d like to know more about the powerful impact of AI, this article should be worth your time. How AI, Machine Learning & Automation Impact Business in 2018 & Beyond

No. First, today’s AI is narrow and weak. When was the last time Siri was given an important problem to address? Instead, we give AIs relatively simple questions such as asking about tomorrow’s weather or the location of the nearest gasoline station. AI here often adds to our capabilities rather than displacing them. At the same time, AI rewards those intelligent enough to ask good questions. At the risk of sounding a braggart, my friends and family think I am some sort of magician for my ability to work with AIs such as Google search. My technique is to form inputs in a way that channels Google or Siri in fruitful directions. That requires a certain level of intelligence.

response.upvotes: Answer requested by Rohit Grover and Marine Poirier

response.answer_text: No. What you are asking about is sometimes called “General AI” (GAI) or “Strong AI”. These are fundamentally different things from what we build today. General AI is aware that it exists and can learn to do things it was not programmed to do. This kind of behavior is not even on the technological horizon. And worse, everyone working in the field knows that our current methods will NEVER get us there. What is needed is a fundamental breakthrough. This is not going to happen in the foreseeable future and there are some arguments that it can never happen. All that said we will be able to build some very useful machines (such as cars that drive themselves) and solve some problems that humans can’t otherwise solve.

No. The two aren’t the same thing. AI is based on the recognition of patterns in prior data and using those patterns to generalize about future events. That’s only part of what human intelligence does. We have no understanding of how Einstein first envisioned special relativity, for example. Could we create an algorithm that would make the logical jumps that lead to such things as relativity, quantum theory, Kant’s Critiques, or Bach’s compositions? Not even close, since we don’t understand how they did what they did. AI can discover new antibiotics but discovering a connection between moldy soy beans and treating infections requires logical connectivity that is limited to higher mammals.

Suppose in the future of technological progress in artificial intelligence, say 50 years from today, artificial intelligence as achieved the IQ of a trillion Einsteins, a trillion Beethovens, a trillion Shakespeares, a trillion Hawkings, a trillion Da Vincis, or a trillion HALs from 2001: A Space Odyssey, etc, ?? Are we to compare this intellectual magnitude to human synaptic and neuronal brain development ?? Most likely by this time, AI will perhaps read our brain Beta waves and become duteous for our economy, our healthcare, and our livelihood by the extreme miniaturization into the molecular level for electronic circuitry. Probabilities and possibilities exist.

The Explainer is a method for using systems of cause-and-effects. Given a system of cause-and-effects, one can find paths through those cause-and-effects from an action that might be considered to find all the consequences of that action. A path is a sequence of effects such that each effect except the last is the cause of the next effect. The effects in each path show the side-effects that would also occur if that action were taken. The principal is quite straight forward but incomplete because the cause-and-effects can form circuits. But how the Explainer uses circuits has already been worked out. The Explainer can be used to produce an AI by providing the AI with these cause-and-effects. An AGI can be created by giving the AI the ability to learn cause-and-effects by interacting with its its environment, looking for candidates for cause-and-effects, then testing them by introducing the cause into its environment to see whether the expected effects occur. If we are afraid of AI’s getting out of control, we can accomplish much of the same ability to solve problems well beyond out current capabilities using the Explainer while keeping the Explainer strictly within our control. steward@problematics.com

Key phrase here is supervised learning(can't use bold..). And to be honest, some of the algorithms we (again..they)use can't seem yet to understand how exactly they work. To answer your question. We are a 10 year old, trying to learn all the concepts of string theory, we are that close..

This is like asking “Will automobiles dominate human locomotion?” We drive cars where we want to go because it is more effective for longer distances, but we also still walk to the car. Same with AI. Analyzing data with AI is more effective for certain kinds of data than doing it using humans to figure it out. You still need to decide what to analyze, and how to get it in a form that the AI can access.

In some people an old Atari program seems more intelligent, lol! But, no, AI will never match human intelligence. It is a digital computer program and totally literal, whereas the human brain is analogue and does not require all the information to deduce the answer. We also possess instinct, the ability for abstract thought, reason, and conceptualisation. Here’s a thought or two. So it is possible that AI may diminish these people’s apparent intelligence.

I think it definitely will dominate human intelligence, eventually. Human intelligence is very limited if you think about it, it’s based on our physical characteristics, for example on the size of the brain. AI’s brain can be far bigger than that, 1 million times bigger. Also, the idea that all human brains linked together (via a certain tech) will be somehow smarter than the smartest person in this collection is false, imho.

It will require perfecting the AI that can master imagination, creativity, and spontaneity, very human traits.In that sense, its a likely NO. For AI to come even close to this, it will require a lot of AI to constantly interact with humans to tap those human traits.Thats actually great, it makes AI more responsive and reliant on humans to succeed, will keep it from becoming adversarial with humans.

A2a. First give me a usable definition of human intelligence. I will work from there. I have friends who cannot pass the Turing test - Wikipedia . But the chess playing computer ‘Deep Blue’ can now outperform doctors in diagnosing disease. See: What Is Using IBM Watson In Everyday Medicine Like? - The Medical Futurist . So, yeah, we’re there. Oh, did I mention self driving cars. (To supersede us they don’t have to be perfect, only better than you; they’re already than me.)

No. But, yes. Only humans can choose to decrease their own intelligence. As with any other technology, humans can choose to use it for better or for worse. Many commentators have complained over several decades that television is to be blamed for reducing the intelligence of humans. So, yes, we might say that the intelligence of a certain proportion of humans is being reduced. But AI is not the cause; the cause is the way in which we humans choose to use it. See HG Wells “The Time Machine” for a fictional example.

Probably, so the question is “when”…and if the answer is far off, will we kill ourselves off first. But you have to suppose that in a million years, technology is likely to be far in advance of what we can imagine today (to be honest, smartphones can do today what I couldn’t have imagined twenty years ago).

No, because human intelligence is based on “the spirit-in-man”. AI is based on the created programming and database created by humans with the “the spirit-in-man”. Each human has a different “the spirit-in-man” programmed by God, with different talents which make humans unique. The brain is the hardware like a computer; but, the hardware needs an operating system, software, to function. The “the spirit-in-man” is our software that allows our brains function.

The further the progress, the narrower the specialization. The AI that plays any champion in chess can no longer do anything. An AI that makes diagnoses better than doctors does not know how to play chess. An AI that knows how to drive cars without drivers doesn’t understand anything in medicine. And assembled all together they do not fit in one room. Too tiny.

Question: Will artificial intelligence dominate human intelligence? Answer: Artificial Intelligence is about the study and research for new algorithms. Question updated: Will algorithms dominate human intelligence? Answer: YES. Human intelligence is dominated by the study and application of algorithms. The execution of algorithms by mechanical means is what we use computers for.

AI is already replacing human intelligence in a host of areas. I am aware of this and I’m no expert on AI. Which tells us that AI is developing faster than most of us are aware. Where will it end? Will it ever end? I have no idea. But we are going to be in for an interesting ride.

No, not unless the AIs want to. Just because one human is really smart doesn’t mean all other humans are obsolete. Humans are social animals that work as a team. Hopefully AIs will simply be good team members.

No! It will be used as a tool by some humans to dominate other humans. Those armed with the tool might be less intelligent than those dominated. In other words it will upset the balance of human Intelligence.

clearly replication is a product of intelligence… living things move towards food and away from toxins… as well as towards another to replicate with someone/thing perceived to be advantageous and away from something perceived to be non-advantageous or toxic… this is intelligent behavior.
AI works faster, not better than human reasoning. AI understands nothing, just blindly calculates. Ingenuity involves much more than calculating.
Not in your lifetime. At this point most AI is fake. AI is not intelligent, it is simply data analysis computer programs.

None. AI can only do what HI tells it or let them ‘learn'. When AI thinks it can have its own mind, pull the plug. AI is just fast, but remains stupid. Try to tell AI the most simple joke and it will just stare at you, blank. Intelligence is not the right description, artificial is right.
Does man reduce the intelligence of ants ? No !!!
